title: Epic: Architecture Refactoring
description:
Architecture Refactoring (High Priority)

1a. Remove AnalyzerAgent Wrapper:
- Priority: Low (no active debugging pain today; mostly a readability/maintainability refactor).
- Status (as of 2026-01-07): Not completed. analyzer_node still instantiates AnalyzerAgent.
- Current state (important nuance): AnalyzerAgent is a thin wrapper around BaseAgent.create() which uses langchain.agents.create_agent(...). There isn't a big custom analyzer graph hidden here; removing the wrapper primarily reduces indirection.
- Potential benefits (why/when to do it):
  - Make the analyzer call path easier to trace end-to-end (node -> wrapper -> base agent -> create_agent).
  - Simplify patching/mocking by relying on a function/module seam instead of a class (if you later standardize agent construction across nodes).
  - Reduce duplication between wrapper "getter" methods and node logic (trace/tool-call/message extraction).
- Risks / cost:
  - Rework unit tests that currently patch AnalyzerAgent directly.
  - If done naively, can increase coupling in analyzernode.py (more code in one place).
- Suggested scope (keep it small if ever done):
  - Prefer extracting a module-level factory like create_analyzer_agent() (or create_analyzer_graph()) and keeping analyzernode.py orchestration-focused.
  - Treat this as preparatory only if you're about to do 1b or broader refactors.
- Acceptance criteria (if pursued):
  - Analyzer behavior unchanged: tool-call detection (request_more_data), trace capture, and final message handling still work.
  - Workflow node key/name (AnalyzerReactAgent) and routing behavior unchanged.
  - Tests updated to patch the new seam and still pass.

1b. Refine Structured Output:
- Status (as of 2026-01-07): Not completed for the analyzer.
  - The query parser already uses structured output (ParsedQuery) and sets state.needs_visualization from parsed_query.wants_visualization.
  - The analyzer still produces freeform text (state.generated_response = ai_message) and does not emit a typed/validated structure.
- Goal: Make analyzer output more reliable for downstream decisions (report vs. request-more-data vs. visualization) by separating:
  - analysis: supporting reasoning / calculations / observations
  - judgment: the direct user-facing answer / conclusion
  - visualization_request: explicit chart intent for reporting only (does not drive state.needs_visualization)
- Why this might matter:
  - Reduces reliance on brittle phrase heuristics (today analyzer uses string detection for REQUEST_MORE_DATA:; visualization intent is primarily driven by parser).
  - Makes reports more consistent (clear "answer" section vs. scratch-work).
- Suggested minimal approach (low risk):
  - Enforce headings/markers in the analyzer prompt template (e.g., require ## Judgment and ## Visualization Request) and parse them into state fields.
- Non-goals:
  - Avoid verbose fallbacks that bloat the codebase. If parsing the structured sections fails, treat the analyzer output as plain text for reporting rather than attempting multi-step recovery.
- Dependencies / ordering:
  - Independent of 1a now (since 1a is low priority). If you ever do 1a, it can make 1b wiring cleaner, but it's not a blocker.
  - Visualization intent remains authoritative from the parser (ParsedQuery.wants_visualization); analyzer visualization_request is informational/reporting only.
- Effort (T-shirt):
  - S/M for "prompt headings + parsing into state".
  - M if you also refactor reporting to render sections separately.

title: Epic: Feature Enhancements
description:
Feature Enhancements (Medium Priority)

3a. Memory Node Re-integration:
- Persist conversation context more effectively to support complex multi-turn queries (e.g., "Compare him to the last player I asked about").

3b. Append/Merge Retrieval:
- Support follow-up queries like "add another player/team" without overwriting existing datasets and implement a deterministic dedupe key strategy.

3c. Visualization Error Handling:
- Add a "retry" mechanism where the LLM can fix its own generated Plotly code if execution fails.

3d. Loop Guardrails:
- Add a retrieve_cycles_remaining counter in ChatbotState to prevent infinite re-retrieval loops.

title: Epic: Testing & Stability
description:
Testing & Stability (High Priority)

2a. Mock External APIs:
- Status (as of 2026-01-07): Not implemented. No VCR/cassette tooling is currently present in test deps.
- Goal: Make integration tests deterministic and CI-safe by eliminating live network dependency from nflreadpy data loads (and any other HTTP side effects used during retrieval).
- Scope:
  - Confirm which HTTP client stack nflreadpy uses (requests/urllib/etc.) and pick the appropriate recording approach (vcrpy if compatible; otherwise an alternative recorder/mocking approach).
  - Introduce a cassette directory (e.g., tests/cassettes/) and a pytest fixture that replays by default.
  - Ensure CI runs in "replay only / no network" mode; recording is a deliberate local/dev action.
  - Include coverage for the implicit "teams preload" + logo download path if it runs during tests.
- Acceptance criteria:
  - uv run pytest tests/integration is deterministic (no flaky network failures).
  - CI passes without requiring external network access for nflreadpy endpoints.
  - Clear workflow for regenerating cassettes (documented command + what to delete/regenerate).
- Note / future migration:
  - This may be revisited once nflreadpy.config.update_config(...) caching is implemented/used in the datasource; at that point, the primary strategy might shift to a well-defined on-disk cache (while optionally keeping VCR for strict offline/no-network runs).
- Effort (T-shirt): M (test harness + cassettes + stabilizing side effects).

2b. Document nflreadpy caching behavior:
- Status (as of 2026-01-07): Not implemented. Datasource has commented-out update_config(...) hooks.
- Goal: Treat caching as a documented feature because it changes runtime behavior, dev ergonomics, and CI performance.
- Scope:
  - Document how caching is configured and where cached data lives.
  - Document how to override caching settings via config/env.
  - Document CI expectations: whether caching is disabled, replay-only (VCR), or pre-warmed.
- Dependencies / ordering:
  - Depends on agreeing the caching surface area (what knobs you will expose in app config vs leaving as library defaults).
  - Should land alongside (or immediately after) enabling update_config(...) in the datasource.
- Acceptance criteria:
  - README (or a short doc under docs/) clearly explains caching defaults + overrides.
  - Contributors can predict whether a run will hit the network and where data will be cached.
- Effort (T-shirt): S/M.
